column1: Sun Prairie is a city in Dane County in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. A suburb of Madison
column2: it is part of the Madison Metropolitan Statistical Area. The city's population was 29
column3: 441 at the 2010 U.S. Census. It is the second-most populous city in Dane County after Madison.

column1: President Martin Van Buren commissioned a party of 45 men
column2: including Augustus A. Bird
column3: to build a capitol for the Territory of Wisconsin in Madison. The group left Milwaukee on May 26
column5: and traveled for days in the rain. On June 9
column6: the group emerged at the edge of the prairie and with the sun shining for the first time in days
column7: carved the words "Sun Prairie" into a tree. Charles Bird returned to the area two years later and became the first settler.The Town of Sun Prairie was created on February 2
column10: was incorporated in an act of the Wisconsin legislature on March 6
column11: 1868. Sun Prairie was incorporated as a city in 1958.

column3: a gas explosion leveled a downtown city block
column4: destroying a bar and a pizza restaurant
column5: as well as damaging the historic old city hall building and multiple other nearby buildings. Bar owner and Fire Captain Cory Barr was injured in the explosion and died as a result soon after. Many citizens and businesses around Sun Prairie offered their support to the Barr family and the affected businesses through fundraising campaigns. This tragic event was the origin of the tagline "Sun Prairie Strong"
column6: a slogan which signifies the city's strength as it comes together as a community.

column1: The Yahara River Valley encompasses part of the city of Sun Prairie. This area contains deep glacial deposits created by the Wisconsin Glaciation. The eastern part of Dane County
column2: known as the drumlin and marsh physiographic area
column3: includes most of Sun Prairie. The deposits found in this area include general glacial deposits and marsh deposits
column4: and consist of many small drumlins interspersed with shallow glacial deposits having poorly defined drainage.

column1: The general soils associations in the Sun Prairie area include the Dodge-St. Charles-McHenry
column2: Plano-Ringwood-Griswold
column3: and Batavia-Houghton-Dresden Associations. The Dodge-St. Charles-McHenry soils are found in the eastern
column4: southern
column5: and central portions of Sun Prairie. This association has a varied landscape
column6: which is mostly sloping
column7: with some areas on benches and in depressions. The Dodge
column8: St. Charles and McHenry soils are well drained to moderately well drained. The Sable soils in this association are nearly level and poorly drained. Most of the soils in this association have moderate permeability and a high available water capacity. Most also have slight to moderate limitations for urban uses and farming.

column1: The landscape of the city consists mostly of gently rolling hills and plains. The elevation of the city averages about 984 feet (300 m) above mean sea level.Sun Prairie has developed a number of traditional neighborhood developments (TND). Often referred to as "new urbanism"
column2: these neighborhoods focus on the pedestrian and the appearance of city streets. While these developments have sought to address the problems and concerns associated with conventional suburban development and urban sprawl
column3: many occupy former farmland and undeveloped rural lands. The city's planners addressed the criticisms that they were "attempting to recreate "pretend" neighborhoods" by noting that the aim of the TND was to borrow those design ideas and features effective in older neighborhoods and adapting them to current needs.

column2: Sun Prairie is in the warm summer humid continental climate zone (Dfa). Summers tend to be hot and humid. The warmest month of the year is July
column3: with an average maximum temperature of 82.1 °F (27.8 °C) and the coldest month of the year is January
column4: with an average minimum temperature of 9.3 °F (−12.6 °C). Temperature variations between night and day tend to be moderate during summer with an average difference of 21 °F (12 °C)
column5: and fairly limited during winter with an average difference of 16 °F (9 °C).

column1: The annual average precipitation at Sun Prairie is 32.95 inches (837 mm). Rainfall is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year
column2: and the wettest month of the year is August with an average rainfall of 4.33 inches (110 mm).

column1: The city of Sun Prairie encounters occasional flooding because of the presence of hydric soils
column2: spring melting and its proximity to the Koshkonong Creek. This condition is compounded by storm water runoff from development and urbanization in the upper reaches of the watershed. Many residents of the city believe that the problems with flooding are worsening
column3: becoming more frequent over the last 14 years.A flood on April 11
column5: caused by heavy overnight rains that outpaced the city's storm drain system and leaked into the sewer system
column6: resulted in flooding in residential basements. The city suffered considerably from the June 2008 Midwest floods.

column1: Sun Prairie has a mayor–council form of government. The mayor is elected at large every odd-numbered year. Paul Esser was elected mayor on April 7
column3: when he defeated challenger Bill Clausius.The city council consists of eight alderpersons
column4: who along with the mayor
column5: make up the Common Council. There are four aldermanic districts
column6: with two alderpersons per district
column7: each serving for two-year terms over alternating years. The council manages the city's budget and financial operations and determines the salaries of all officers and employees of the city.

column1: Sun Prairie has a full-time city administrator
column2: who is responsible for the administration of the city government in accordance with the policies established by the Common Council. Other city officers consist of assistant administrator
column3: City Clerk
column4: treasurer
column6: municipal judge Tom Hebl
column7: police chief and fire chief.

Sun Prairie has a combination fire department that serves both the city and town of Sun Prairie
column2: as well as the towns of Burke and Bristol. The department
column3: which began in 1891
column4: consists of 45 members who maintain external jobs
column5: 14 career staff and 8 LTE positions. The fire department has ten fire engines and two vintage vehicles
column6: a 1927 Stoughton fire engine refurbished by a past fire department chief and a second 1927 Stoughton fire engine that was Sun Prairie's first motorized fire truck. This was refurbished at the direction of Captain Cory Barr

column1: The EMS was founded in October 1977 as an extension of the local police department. The city's rapid growth affected ambulance response times negatively
column2: and the 1980s saw the hiring of a full-time EMS director. In the 1980s and 1990s
column3: most of the service was slowly replaced by full-time EMTs. In the 1990s
column4: the service made a transition from EMT-basic personnel to that of intravenous technician levels and paramedic level.Sun Prairie EMS transports to all Madison hospitals and to Columbus Community Hospital in Columbus. In 2009 St. Mary's Hospital of Madison opened a free-standing emergency room facility in Sun Prairie.

column1: The city owns its own utilities

column1: The Sun Prairie Family Aquatic Center (FAC) is a municipal swimming pool that serves the Sun Prairie area. Opened on May 30
column3: it replaced the previous municipal pool that opened in 1958 in Angell Park. The Family Aquatic Center has an 18-foot drop slide
column4: two diving boards
column6: and a 210-foot water slide. There are play structures and sand volleyball courts inside the pool compound. The Sun Prairie Piranhas
column7: the city's youth swim team
column8: practice at the Family Aquatic Center. They are a member of the Tri-County Swimming Conference.

1990 Census data indicates that most Sun Prairie residents drive their own vehicles to work (79.4%). A fair number of residents use carpooling as their primary transportation to work (13.4%). Other methods of transportation remain a minor factor.
I-39 runs concurrently with I-90 from Illinois to Portage. In Madison
column2: they are joined by I-94 until Portage. This overlap occurs in the area immediately between the metropolitan city of Madison and Sun Prairie.

column1: I-90 runs east–west through the western
column2: central and southern portions of the state
column3: and is located to the west of Sun Prairie. A total of 187 miles (301 km) of Interstate 90 lie in Wisconsin; the Madison exit (designated 135B) leads to US 151 North and Sun Prairie.

column1: I-94 as it occurs in Wisconsin runs east–west through the western
column2: central and southeastern portions of the state. The junction of I-90 and i-94 occurs roughly six miles to the southwest of Sun Prairie heading eastward toward Milwaukee at what is commonly known as the "Badger Interchange" where the three interstates (I-39
column3: I-90 and I-94) meet at the eastern terminus of WIS 30.

column2: 151 or US-151) is a freeway in Sun Prairie that runs northeast–southwest across the eastern to southwest portions of the state. Sun Prairie is divided lengthwise by US-151
column3: southwest to northeast

column2: STH 19 or WIS 19) is a state highway which passes around the north side of Madison and crosses US-151 as it passes through Sun Prairie. It serves as a local connector route that links via various interchanges the communities of Sun Prairie
column3: Watertown and Waunakee. The roadway follows two-lane surface road for the entire length with the exception of urban multilane arterials.Prior to 1947
column4: WIS 19 followed the current route of US-18 between Bridgeport and Madison. The route then passed through downtown Madison and followed then WIS 31 (part of the current US-151) to Sun Prairie. East of Sun Prairie the route followed its present-day alignment to Watertown. The route then followed present-day WIS 16 to Waukesha and east from there along present-day WIS 59 into Milwaukee.  When the U.S. Highway system was implemented
column5: WIS 19's western terminus was relocated to Madison. The portion between Madison and Sun Prairie remained despite the debut of US-151 as did the eastern portion that became concurrent with US-16. In 1947
column6: the eastern terminus was moved to Watertown
column7: the section along US-151 was removed
column8: and the portion between Mazomanie and Sun Prairie was implemented.The part of WIS 19 roughly from those interstates west to WIS 113 had at one time been on the corridor of a planned beltline route around the north side of Madison. The current status of the parkway is uncertain.

column1: Sun Prairie is bordered by the following county roads:
C (also named N. Grand Avenue) runs north–south and borders Sun Prairie to the west and is crossed by interchange by US-151.
N (also named N. Bristol Street) runs north–south and bisects a third of the city to the west and is crossed by interchange by US-151.
VV (also named Twin Lane Road) runs north–south and borders the city to the east and is crossed by interchange by US-151.

column1: Although Sun Prairie has tracks for freight trains to the south of the city
column2: the only passenger train to serve the area is Amtrak's Empire Builder
column3: which operates in the Midwestern and Northwestern United States. The route runs from Chicago to the Pacific Northwest
column4: arriving in nearby Columbus (CBS). The ridership on the train has increased slowly
column6: 850 per year traveling to and from Columbus
column7: despite the population growth in Sun Prairie. Travel time to and from Chicago is slightly under three hours.

column1: Sun Prairie's Jimmy the Groundhog is the local favorite on Groundhog Day in February. The United States Congressional Record described the city as the "Groundhog Capital of the World" in 1955. During the city's Groundhog Day celebration on February 2
column3: Jimmy bit Mayor Jonathan Freund's ear. The next day
column4: Freund issued a proclamation that pardoned and absolved Jimmy "of any perceived wrongdoing and charges" under the city's ordinances. Two weeks later
column5: Freund came in last of three candidates in the city's mayoral primary election. Following the biting incident
column6: the United States Department of Agriculture and the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources declared that capturing wild animals for exhibit was against the law. Sun Prairie's next Groundhog Day celebration on February 2
column8: featured a caged groundhog purchased for $1
column10: the city holds a local Taste of the Arts fair
column11: in conjunction with the Georgia O'Keeffe Celebration. Artwork is exhibited and instructional classes for arts and crafts are held. A Georgia O'Keeffe recreation discussion is held.The Flags of Freedom Field Show is a day-long series of events in July
column12: involving high-school marching band competitions with bands from throughout the United States and Canada. It is hosted by the Sound of Sun Prairie.In mid-August of each year
column13: Sun Prairie hosts a Sweet Corn Festival. Over 70 short tons (63 t)of sweet corn are served or sold during the weekend event
column15: a parade down Main Street and performances by local and regional musical groups.
